questions.text: As per travel regulations after how many days following yellow fever vaccination is a person eligible to travel?
questions.solution:
Yellow fever vaccine:

  • For international use, the approved vaccine is the 17D vaccine.
  • It is a live attenuated vaccine prepared from a non-virulent strain (17D strain), which is grown in chick embryo and subsequently freeze-dried.
  • Route: Subcutaneously
  • Dose: 0.5 ml
  • All travellers (including infants) exposed to the risk of yellow fever or passing through endemic zones of yellow fever must possess a valid international certificate of vaccination against yellow fever before they are allowed to enter yellow fever "receptive" areas.
  • India and most other countries require a valid certificate of vaccination against yellow fever from travellers coming from infected areas.
  • The validity of the certificate begins 10 days after the date of vaccination.
  • For the purpose of international travel, the vaccination must be given at an officially designated centre, and the certificate must be validated with the official stamp of the Ministry of Health, Government of India.

Reference- K Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 8, Page no. 329

Topic- Communicable disease, yellow fever

questions.text: A 45-year-old male working in cotton industry, complaints of breathlessness and cough for past 6 months. His breathlessness intensifies on Monday. He visited the Primary Health Center for advice. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Diseases due to physical agents

(1) Heat- Heat hyperpyrexia, heat exhaustion, heat syncope, heat cramps, burns and local effects such as prickly heat.

(2) Cold- Trench foot, frost bite, chilblains

(3) Light- Occupational cataract, miner's nystagmus

(4) Pressure- Caisson disease, air embolism, blast(explosion)

(5) Noise- Occupational deafness

(6) Radiation- Cancer, leukaemia, aplastic anaemia, pancytopenia

(7) Mechanical factors- Injuries, accidents

(8) Electricity- Burns.

  • Diseases due to chemical agents

(1) Gases: Co2. CO, HCN, CS2, NH3, N2, H2S, HCl, so2- these cause gas poisoning,

(2) Dusts (Pneumoconiosis)

(i) Inorganic dusts

(a) Coal dust- Anthracosis

(b) Silica- Silicosis

(c) Asbestos- Asbestosis, cancer lung

(d) Iron- Siderosis

(ii) Organic (vegetable) dusts

(a) Cane fibre- Bagassosis

(b) Cotton dust- Byssinosis

(c)Tobacco- Tobacossis

(d) Hay or grain dust- Farmers' lung

(3) Metals and their compounds

(4) Toxic hazards from lead, mercury, cadmium, manganese, beryllium, arsenic, chromium etc.

(5) Chemicals : Acids, alkalies, pesticides

(6) Solvents : Carbon bisulphide, benzene, trichloroethylene, chloroform, etc.

III. Diseases due to biological agents:

Brucellosis, leptospirosis, anthrax, actinomycosis,

hydatidosis, psittacosis, tetanus, encephalitis,

fungal infections, etc.

  • Occupational cancers:

Cancer of skin, lungs, bladder.

  • Occupational dermatosis

Dermatitis, eczema.

  • Diseases of psychological origin

Reference- K. Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 18, Page No. 933

questions.solution:
Zinc :

  • antioxidant agent
  • required for synthesis of insulin by pancreas.
  • Sources : animal food- fish meat milk
  • Deficiency causes: loss of taste

    • decrease insulin synthesis
    • growth failure

    • impair cell mediated immunity
    • delayed wound healing
    • pernicious anemia
    • thalassemia
    • myocardial infraction
    • hepatomegaly
  • Zinc deficiency in pregnancy causes: spontaneous abortion

IUGR

  • Preterm delivery
  • low birth weight
  • congenital malformation
  • Toxicity: pulmonary fibrosis

Topic- Nutrition

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary toxin responsible for neurolathyrism?
questions.solution:
BMAA (beta-methylamino alanine): While also a neurotoxin, BMAA is primarily associated with certain cyanobacteria and cycad plants. Although some studies suggest its potential involvement in other neurodegenerative diseases, it has not been directly linked to neurolathyrism.

beta-cycasin: Another cycad-derived toxin, BMAA (beta-cycasin) is distinct from BMAA (beta-methylaminoalanine) and doesn't play a role in neurolathyrism.

ODAP (3-oxalyldiaminopropionic acid): Another excitotoxic amino acid, ODAP is present in Lathyrus odoratus (sweet pea) and causes a different form of lathyrism called osteolathyrism. This condition mainly affects bone and connective tissue, rather than the nervous system as in neurolathyrism.

BOAA: Found in certain Lathyrus species like grass peas (Lathyrus sativus), this neurotoxin has been demonstrated to be the primary cause of neurolathyrism. It disrupts glutamate metabolism in the nervous system, leading to cell death and neurodegeneration, particularly in motor neurons. This results in the characteristic spastic paralysis and muscle weakness associated with the disease.

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. In the humans it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system, and in animals as osteolathyrism (odoratism) because the pathological changes occur in the bones resulting in skeletal deformities Neurolathyrism is a crippling disease of the nervous system characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of lower limbs, occurring mostly in adults consuming the pulse, Lathyrus sativus in large quantities.

The cause of neurolathyrism is a toxin, Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) which is found in the seeds of the pulse, L.sativus (Khesari dhal). Neurolathyrism is a public health problem in certain parts of the country where this pulse is eaten.

Reference- K. Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 11, Page No. 759

Topic- Nutrition

questions.text: 40 years old Mr. Joseph reported to your hospital with complaints of fever, myalgia, conjunctival suffusion, pain in abdomen, jaundice, and scanty micturition of 5days duration. O/E. puffiness of face is present, and liver is palpable and tender. By occupation he is a farmer involved in paddy cultivation. There has been an increase in the number of cases of fever attending your OPD since last month following heavy rainfall lasting 5 days. Which of the following is incorrect about this case?
questions.solution:
Leptospirosis

  • an infectious disease caused by pathogenic organisms belonging to the genus Leptospira, that are transmitted directly or indirectly from animals to humans.
  • Leptospirosis is a major direct zoonosis.
  • Human to-human transmission occurs very rarely.

Mode of Transmission

  • through the urine of infected animals, which can get into water or soil and can survive there for weeks to months. Many diferent kinds of wild and domestic animals carry the bacterium, which include cattle, pigs, horses, dogs, rodents etc.
  • Humans can become infected through:
  • Contact with urine (or other body fluids, except saliva) from infected animals.
  • Contact with water, soil, or food contaminated with the urine of infected animals.
  • The bacteria can enter the body through skin or mucous membranes (eyes, nose, or mouth), especially if the skin is broken from a cut or scratch.
  • Drinking contaminated water can also cause infection.

Signs and Symptoms

  • incubation period of average 5-14 days with a range 2-30 days.

four broad clinical categories:

  1. A mild, influenza-like illness
  2. Weil's syndrome is characterized by jaundice, renal failure, haemorrhage and myocarditis with arrhythmias.
  • Meningitis/ meningoencephalitis
  1. Pulmonary haemorrhage with respiratory failure.

Treatment

  • Adults: Doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for seven days
  • Pregnant and lactating mothers should be given capsule ampicillin 500 mg every six hourly
  • Children<8 years: Amoxycillin/Ampicillin 30-50 mg/kg/day in divided doses for 7 days

Reference- K. Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 5, Page No. 338

Topic- Communicable disease, zoonotic disease

questions.text: A daily wager approaches ANM for complaints of cough with sputum and fever persisting for three weeks. He never had similar symptoms in the past, and no other member of his family is currently facing similar health issues. Which of the following is false for the patient?
questions.solution:
Newer initiatives:

  1. NIKSHAY :
  • TB surveillance using case based, web based IT system
  • Central TB Division in collaboration with National Informatics Centre has undertaken the initiative to develop application named Nikshay.
  • combination of two Hindi words NI and KSHAY meaning eradication Of TB.
  • This software was launched in May 2012 and has following functional components:

-Master management

-User details

-TB patient registration and details of diagnosis, DOT provider, HIV status follow-up, contact tracing, outcomes.

-Details of solid and liquid culture and DST, LPA, CBNAAT details.

-DR-TB patient registration with details.

-Referral and transfer of patients.

-Private health facility registration and TB notification.

-Mobile application for TB notification.

-SMS alerts to patients on registration,

-SMS alerts to programme officers.

-Automated periodic reports:

  1. Case finding
  2. Sputum conversion
  3. Treatment outcome.
  • The programme has started using IT enabled adherence tools like 99 DOTS for HIV-TB patients. This will be expanded to all TB patients with implementation of daily regimen
  1. TB Notification
  • In order to ensure proper diagnosis and management of TB cases and reduce TB transmission and the emergence and spread of MDR-TB, it is essential to have complete information of all TB cases.
  • It is now mandatory for all healthcare providers to notify every TB case to local authorities every month in a given format.
  1. Ban on TB Serology
  • The serological tests are based on antibody response, which is highly variable in TB and may reflect remote infection rather than active disease.
  • Currently available serological tests are having poor specificity and should not be used for the diagnosis of pulmonary or extra-pulmonary TB. Their import, manufacturing. sale, distribution and use is banned by the Government of India.
  1. Direct benefit transfer schemes
  • Direct beneficiary transfer systems are being established by linking TB patients reported in NIKSHAY with AADHAR and PEMS to effectively deliver benefits to TB patients and their providers.

Reference- K. Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 7, Page No. 488

Topic- Communicable disease, TB

questions.text: Mr. Rajesh a 45-year-old male was admitted to the medical college hospital with a history of high-grade fever for the past 7 days associated with severe body aches, joint pain, retro orbital pain & and gastrointestinal symptoms. On examination patient was febrile (102°F) with rashes on the face, neck & and chest. Purpuric spots were observed in the palate & and inner part of the oral cavity. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Dengue Fever

Clinical manifestations

  1. Undifferentiated fever
  • develops simple fever indistinguishable from other viral infection
  • rashes may appear during deferevescence
  1. Dengue fever
  • sudden onset with chills high fever headache muscle and joint pain
  • within 24 hour retroorbital pain and photophobia
  • skin eruption appeared during second February phase which lasts for two days
  • rashes may be followed by desquamation
  • fever last for 5 days

Reference- K. Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 5, Page No. 286

questions.text: What does the acronym DASH stand for?
questions.solution:
DASH Diet -Dietary Approach to Stop Hypertension

This includes eating vegetables, fruits, and whole grains. This diet ensures consumption of food that is less saturated. and trans-fats, low fat dairy products, food that is rich in proteins, minerals like calcium, magnesium, potassium, and fiber. This diet plan also restricts use of sweetened foods and beverages.


Reference- IAPSM, 2nd edition, Chapter 19, page 489

Topic- NCD

choices.text: Increased focus on chronic disease management
Need for preventive measures against infectious diseases
Shift in healthcare resources towards noncommunicable diseases
Emergence of new drug therapies for noncommunicable diseases

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT likely a consequence of the epidemiological transition?
questions.solution:
While the epidemiological transition signifies a shift towards noncommunicable diseases taking center stage as leading causes of mortality and morbidity, infectious diseases are not entirely eradicated or rendered irrelevant. While their burden generally decreases, they still pose a significant threat and require continued preventive measures.


Here's a breakdown of the remaining options and why they are likely consequences of the epidemiological transition:

(a) Increased focus on chronic disease management: As noncommunicable diseases become more prevalent, healthcare systems need to adapt and prioritize resources for effective chronic disease management.

(c) Shift in healthcare resources towards noncommunicable diseases: This aligns directly with the transition, as resources need to be allocated to address the rising burden of noncommunicable diseases.

(d) Emergence of new drug therapies for noncommunicable diseases: This directly reflects one of the consequences of the transition, as research and development efforts shift towards tackling noncommunicable diseases, leading to advancements in their treatment.

Reference- IAPSM, 2nd edition, Chapter 18, page 482

Topic- Communicable disease

Topic- Health care infrastructure

choices.text: Routine antenatal care and immunization services

questions.text: Which of the following is essential for a PHC to be considered a 24x7 facility?
questions.solution:
The existing PHCs are upgraded in several states to provide continuous and round-the-clock delivery services. The criteria/ requirements for declaring a PHC as 24 x 7 PHC are described below. However, these requirements are in addition to the primary services which a PHC is routinely expected to provide. Essential additional services to be provided by a PHC to be considered as a 24 x 7 PHC are:

  1. Provision of uninterrupted 24 x 7 delivery service, both assisted and normal*
  2. Essential newborn care
  3. Immediate referral for mother and child health emergencies to appropriate predetermined referral centers*
  4. Routine antenatal care and routine immunization services for children and pregnant women (in addition to fixed day services).
  5. Postnatal care
  6. Early and safe services for medical termination of pregnancy (including manual vacuum aspiration)
  7. Family welfare services
  8. Prevention and management of reproductive tract infections
  9. Essential laboratory services related to pregnancy, newborn care and children.

For providing these services the technical staff of PHC particularly the medical officers and the staff nurses will be provided training on basic emergency obstetric care.

The goal of the union government is to upgrade all PHC to 24 x 7 PHC. However, it is not immediately possible. Hence, the government has formulated a checklist to rank and prioritize the PHCs to be upgraded for continuous functioning. The checklist essentially grades the PHC based on scoring of the following elements: location of the facility and its accessibility, population size, presence of technical staff at the facility and staff quarters, number of deliveries conducted annually, functional labor room, availability of referral services, other health facilities in the locality, etc.

Reference- IAPSM, 2nd edition, Chapter 46, page 866

Topic- Health care infrastructure

choices.text: General Out-patient Care for Acute Simple Illnesses and Minor Ailments
Care for Common Ophthalmic and ENT Problem
Childhood and Adolescent Health Care Services

questions.text: Which of the following services is NOT typically offered at a Health and Wellness Centre (HWC)?
questions.solution:
While HWCs might manage emergencies and stabilize patients, they typically lack the infrastructure and equipment to perform blood transfusions. These require specialized facilities and equipment available at hospitals or larger medical centers. Therefore, this is not a service typically offered at an HWC.


List of services offered at a Health and Wellness Centre (HWC)

  1. Care in Pregnancy and Childbirth.
  2. Neonatal and Infant Health Care Services
  3. Childhood and Adolescent Health Care Services.
  4. Family Planning, Contraceptive Services and other Reproductive Health Care Services
  5. Management of Communicable Diseases: National Health Programmes
  6. General Out-patient Care for Acute Simple Illnesses and Minor Ailments
  7. Screening, Prevention, Control and Management of Non-communicable Diseases and Chronic Communicable diseases like Tuberculosis and Leprosy.
  8. Basic Oral Health Care
  9. Emergency Medical Services including Burns and Trauma
  10. Care for Common Ophthalmic and ENT Problem
  11. Elderly and Palliative Health Care Services
  12. Screening and Basic Management of Mental Health Ailments

Topic- Health care infrastructure

Reference- K. Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 10, Page No. 707

questions.solution: Topic- Preventive medicine in obstetrics, Paediatrics, and geriatrics

choices.text: Enlist local Dai's in their areas

questions.text: All are true regarding Female health worker (FHW) except
questions.solution:
Functions of FHW:

  • Ensure that every pregnant woman makes atleast 4 (four) visits for antenatal check-up according to suggested schedule.
  • Supervise deliveries conducted by Dais and assist them whenever called in.
  • Tracking of all pregnancies by name for scheduled ANC/PNC services.
  • Make post-natal home visits on 0, 3, 7 and 42nd day for deliveries at home and sub-centre and on 3, 7, and 42nd day for institutional delivery. Post-natal visits are to be made for each delivery happened in her area and she should render advice regarding care of the mother and care and feeding of the newborn.
  • In case of low birth weight baby, a total of six post natal visits are to be made on O, 3, 7, 14, 21 and 28th day to screen for congenital abnormalities, assess the neonate for danger signs of sickness etc. as per IMNCI guidelines and appropriate referral. Initiation of early breast-feeding within one hour of birth, exclusive breast-feeding for 6 months and timely weaning at 6 months as per infant and young child feeding guidelines.
  • Establish female depot holders, and provide a conventional of supply continuous contraceptives to the depot holders.
  • Build rapport with acceptors, village leaders, ASHA, Dais and others and utilize them for promoting Family Welfare Programme.

Reference- K. Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 10, Page No. 713

Topic- Preventive medicine in obstetrics, Paediatrics, and geriatrics

questions.text: Breast feeding week is celebrated on.
questions.solution: Topic- Preventive medicine in obstetrics, Paediatrics, and geriatrics

questions.text: Recent number of maternal deaths per lakh live birth is
questions.solution:
Maternal mortality rate (MMRate):

  • Defined and calculated as the number of maternal deaths divided by person-years lived by women of reproductive age in a population.
  • It captures both the risk of maternal death per pregnancy or per birth (whether live birth or still birth, and the level of fertility in the population (i.e. both factors mentioned above).

Maternal mortality ratio (MMR):

  • Defined as the number of maternal deaths during a given time period per 1,00,000 live births during the same time period
  • Quantifies the risk of maternal death relative to the number of live births

Reference- K. Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 9, Page No. 637

Topic- Preventive medicine in obstetrics, Paediatrics, and geriatrics
